BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
§ 33.01 CREATION; DUTIES AND FUNCTIONS.
   There is hereby created a Board of Local Improvements in and for the city to
do and perform all the duties and functions incumbent upon and exercise all the
rights of a Board of Local Improvements, all as provided in and by an Act of
the General Assembly of the state entitled, “An Act Concerning Local
Improvements,” approved June 14, 1897, and all acts amendatory thereof or
supplemental thereto.
(Ord. 553, passed 4-19-76)
§ 33.02 DESIGNATION OF MEMBERS.
   The four members of the City Council and the Mayor are hereby designated and
appointed members of the Board of Local Improvements of the city. The Council
members along with the Mayor shall constitute the Board with the Mayor serving
as President of the Board.
('72 Code, § 3.13) (Am. Ord. 554, passed 4-19-76)
BAND COMMISSION
§ 33.10 CREATION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS, TERM.
   There is hereby created a Band Commission for the city which shall consist
of five members. The members of the Commission shall be appointed by the Mayor
by and with the advice and consent of the City Council. Their term of office
shall be for one year or until their successor is duly appointed.
('72 Code, § 3.14(a))
§ 33.11 CHARGE AND SUPERVISION OF MONEYS.
   The Band Commission shall have charge and supervision of all money therefor,
provided that no such money shall be spent without the approval of the City
Council.
('72 Code, § 3.14(b))
§ 33.12 CHARGE OF APPOINTMENT OF BAND MEMBERS.
   The Band Commission shall have charge of the appointment of a band master
and shall select and appoint the members of the band.
('72 Code, § 3.14(c))
§ 33.13 LEVY OF TAX.
   The special tax provided for by the act in relation to the employment or
maintaining of musical bands by municipalities shall be levied and collected
for the uses therein specified, but no such money shall be paid out of the Band
Fund except on order of the Band Commission.
('72 Code, § 3.14(d))
Statutory reference:
   For provisions concerning petition for referendum for tax levy, see ILCS Ch.
65, Act 5, § 11-45-1

shall possess all of the powers and be subject to all of the responsibilities
under the provisions of Article 11, Division 95 of the Illinois Municipal Code.

   It is determined that the power to establish, conduct and maintain a

('72 Code, § 3.15(a))

Chapter 96

   The Recreation Board shall be composed of seven members, to be appointed by
the Mayor with the consent of the corporate authorities.
(Ord. 1810, passed 12-15-21)
BOARD OF HEALTH
§ 33.35 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Department of the Municipal Government of the
city which shall be known as the Board of Health and which Board shall embrace
all the members of the City Council.
('72 Code, § 11.01(a))
§ 33.36 CHAIRPERSON OF BOARD.
   The Chairperson of the Board of Health shall be the Commissioner of Public
Health and Safety, and the Chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the
Board. In his absence, the Mayor shall act as such Chairperson.
('72 Code, § 11.01(b))
§ 33.37 MEETINGS.
   The Board of Health shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, or in his
absence or disability to act, at the call of the majority of the members of the
Board.
('72 Code, § 11.01(c))
§ 33.38 DUTIES.
   (A)   The Board of Health shall have the general supervision of the interest
of the public health of the city. The Board shall have authority to make such
rules and regulations and such sanitary investigation as they may from time to
time deem necessary for the preservation and improvement of the public health,
and they are empowered to make such regulations, not inconsistent with the laws
of the state, as may be necessary to at all times prevent the spread of any
contagious or pestilential disease. It shall be the duty of all officers,
police officers and other employees of the city to enforce the rules and
regulations that may be adopted by the Board.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the Board to investigate into the cause of
dangerously contagious or infectious disease, especially when existing in
epidemic form and take means to restrict and suppress the same, and whenever
any dangerously contagious or infectious disease shall become, or threaten to
become, epidemic in the city, the Board shall immediately take all necessary
steps provided for by law to suppress the same.
('72 Code, § 11.01(d))
§ 33.39 HEALTH OFFICER; CREATION OF OFFICE; DUTIES; BOND.
   (A)   Creation of office. There is hereby created and established the office
of Health Officer.
   (B)   Duties. The Health Officer shall be under the direction and
supervision of the Commissioner of Public Health and Safety, and shall perform
such duties and superintend such work as the Commissioner may direct. He shall
be a regular practicing physician, and shall give the Board of Health and other
city authorities such professional advice and information as they may require
with a view to the preservation of the public health.
   (C)   Bond. The Health Officer shall, before entering upon the duties of his
office, execute a bond to the city in the penal sum of $500, with such sureties
as the City Council shall approve, conditioned for the faithful performance of
the duties of his office, and shall also take and subscribe the oath prescribed
by law for city officers.
('72 Code, § 11.02)
WATER AND SEWER BILLING REVIEW BOARD
§ 33.40 CREATION.
   There is hereby established a Water and Sewer Billing Review Board for the
purpose of hearing complaints as to water and sewer billings. The Board shall
appoint a chairperson and a secretary and such other officers as they desire.
(Ord. 1737, passed 2-5-20)
§ 33.41 MEMBERS.
   The members of the Water and Sewer Billing Review Board shall consist of the
Commissioner of Public Property, the City Clerk, the City Treasurer, the
Superintendent of the Waste Water Treatment Plant and the City Engineer or
their designee.
(Ord. 1737, passed 2-5-20)
§ 33.42 RESPONSIBILITIES AND POWERS.
   The Water and Sewer Billing Review Board shall meet the first and third
Wednesdays at 1:00 p.m. with the duty to seek resolution of disputes over water
and sewer billings. Upon the concurrence of three or more members, the Board
may:
   (A)   Grant relief to any dispute over water and sewer billings not
involving a loss of potential revenue to the city of more than $50. Any dispute
resolution involving a loss of potential revenue to the city of more than $50
shall be approved only by the concurrence of a majority of the members of the
City Council.
   (B)   The Board may approve a bill payment agreement. A bill payment
agreement shall require payment of all delinquencies within 18 months. A bill
payment agreement may require that a lien be recorded as to delinquencies to
date. A bill payment agreement may direct that water or sewer service be
restored. The Board may not agree to the bill payment agreement within 12
months from the date of default of any prior bill payment agreement.
   (C)   For good cause, the Board may request the testing of a meter and the
replacement of an apparently malfunctioning meter (see § 52.52 TESTING OF
METERS; FILING OF COMPLAINT AFTER INVESTIGATION of the Code of Marseilles).
   (D)   The Board may request one or more additional meter readings and may
request the attendance of a meter reader at a meeting.
   (E)   The Board may make recommendations to the City Council for
improvements to the meter reading and billing systems.
(Ord. 1737, passed 2-5-20)
§ 33.43 COMPLAINT PROCESS.
   (A)   A city water or sewer user or their power of attorney or their
attorney shall initiate a complaint in writing stating the nature of the
dispute or problem and the relief requested. Where the complaining party is not
the property owner, the property owner must join in the complaint. Where a
complaint is initiated by a power of attorney, the Board may require that the
power of attorney document be produced. Complaints shall be filed at City Hall.
The filing of a complaint shall not act a stay of a scheduled water or sewer
shutoff.
   (B)   The Chairperson shall use diligent effort to call a meeting with the
complaining party and a quorum of the members of the Water and Sewer Billing
Review Board within seven days. Absent good cause shown by the complaining
party, all meetings shall be held at the City Hall. The complaining party may
attend the hearing by telephone. The Chairperson of the Board may continue a
meeting as reasonably required. The complaining party may for good cause
request one continued hearing, The Secretary shall maintain meeting minutes and
the Chairperson may maintain recordings of hearings. The Chairperson may
require that testimony be presented under oath. The Chairperson may recess or
adjourn a meeting when the Chairperson has concern that a police officer needs
to be in attendance to maintain order.
(Ord. 1737, passed 2-5-20)
COMBINED PLAN COMMISSION AND ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS
§ 33.50 PURPOSE.
   In order that adequate provisions be made for the preparation of a
comprehensive city plan for the guidance, direction and control of the growth
and development of the city, a combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of
Appeals, which shall be a department of the city government, is hereby created
under authority of the Illinois Municipal Code.
(‘72 Code, § 21.01(a)) (Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
Statutory reference:
   For provisions concerning plan commissions, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 11-
12-4 et seq.
§ 33.51 MEMBERSHIP.
   The combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals shall consist of
seven Zoning Board of Appeals members also serving as Planning Commission
members. The Zoning Board of Appeals members shall reside within the city. The
remaining members of the Plan Commission shall reside within the municipality
or within territory contiguous to the municipality and not more than one and
one-half miles beyond the municipality’s corporate limits. One or more Plan
Commission members not members of the Zoning Board of Appeals may be appointed
as alternate members of the Zoning Board of Appeals to fill in for an absent
Zoning Board of Appeals member.
(‘72 Code, § 21.01(b)) (Am. Ord. 1384, passed 8-5-09; Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-
7-21)
§ 33.52 TERM OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.
   The seven members of the combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of
Appeals serving as Plan Commission members shall serve terms of office as
established by Section 11-13-3 of the Illinois Municipal Code. Plan Commission
members not members of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall serve four-year terms
appointed following City Council elections. The City Council by proper
resolution shall fill all vacancies as they occur.
(‘72 Code, § 21.01(c)) (Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
§ 33.53 PROCEDURE OF COMMISSION FOLLOWING APPOINTMENT.
   Immediately following their appointment, the members of the combined Plan
Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals shall meet, organize and elect such
officers as it may deem necessary, and adopt and later change or alter rules
and regulations of organization and procedure consistent with this code, any
applicable ordinances of the city, and state laws. The combined Commission and
Board shall keep written records of its proceedings, which shall be open at all
times to public inspection. The combined Commission and Board shall also file
an annual report with the Mayor and City Council, setting forth its
transactions and recommendations.
(‘72 Code, § 21.01(d)) (Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
§ 33.54 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals shall have
the following powers and duties with respect to actions as a Plan Commission:
      (1)   To prepare and recommend to the City Council a comprehensive plan
of public improvements, looking to the present and future developments and
growth of the city. Such a plan after its adoption by the Council shall be
known as the official plan of the city.
      (2)   To prepare and recommend to the Council from time to time, such
changes in the plan or any part thereof as may be deemed necessary by the
Council or the combined Commission and Board.
      (3)   To prepare and recommend to the Council from time to time, plans
and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance to the official
plan.
      (4)   To give aid to officials of the city charged with the direction of
projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further the
making of such improvements, and generally to promote the realization of the
official plan.
      (5)   To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its
activities from the general purpose of public understanding.
      (6)   To cooperate with municipal and regional planning commissions and
other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure
harmonious and integrated planning for the area.
      (7)   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted under
authority of the Illinois Municipal Code as may be conferred by the Council.
      (8)   To designate land suitable for annexation to the city and the
recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation.
   (B)   The combined Planning Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals shall
have powers and duties as a Zoning Board of Appeals as established by the
Marseilles Zoning Ordinance and Division 13 Zoning in Article 11 Corporate
Powers and Functions of the Illinois Municipal Code.
(‘72 Code, § 21.02) (Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
§ 33.55 COPIES OF ORDINANCES, PLANS AND DATA RELATIVE TO PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS TO
BE FURNISHED TO COMMISSION.
   The City Clerk shall furnish the combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board
of Appeals for its consideration a copy of all ordinances, plans and data
relative to public improvements of any nature. The combined Commission and
Board may report in relation thereto if it deems a report necessary or
advisable, for the consideration of the City Council.
(‘72 Code, § 21.03) (Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
§ 33.56 EXPENDITURES.
   The combined Plan Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals may, at the
discretion of the City Council, employ necessary help whose salaries, wages and
other necessary expenses shall be provided for by adequate appropriation made
by the Council from public funds. If the combined Commission and Board shall
deem it advisable to secure technical advice or services, it may be done upon
authority from the Council and appropriations by the Council therefor.
(‘72 Code, § 21.04) (Am. Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
§ 33.57 LAND SUBDIVISION OR RESUBDIVISION AND THE OFFICIAL MAP.
   (A)   At any time before or after the formal adoption of the official
comprehensive plan by the corporate authorities, an official map may be
designated by ordinance, which map may consist of the whole area included
within the official comprehensive plan, or one or more separate geographical or
functional parts, and may include all or any part of the contiguous
unincorporated area within one and one-half miles from the corporate limits of
the city. All requirements for public hearing, filing of notice of adoption
with the County Recorder of Deeds, and filing of said plan and ordinances,
including the official map, with the City Clerk shall be complied with as
provided for by law.
   (B)   No map or plat of any subdivision or resubdivision presented for
record affecting land within the corporate limits of the city or within
contiguous territory which is not more than one and one-half miles beyond the
corporate limits shall be entitled to record or shall be valid unless the
subdivision shown thereon provides for standards of design, and standards
governing streets, alleys, public ways, ways for public service facilities,
street lights, public grounds, size of lots to be used for residential
purposes, storm and flood water run-off channels and basins, water supply and
distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment in
conformity with all applicable requirements of the this code and any other
ordinances of the city, including the official map.
('72 Code, § 21.05)
§ 33.58 MEETINGS AND HEARING PROCEEDINGS.
   All meetings of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be held at the call of the
Chairman and at such times and places within the city as the Zoning Board of
Appeals may determine. All testimony by witnesses at any hearing provided for
in the zoning ordinance shall be given under oath. The Chairman, or in his or
her absence, the acting Chairman, may administer oaths and compel the
attendance of witnesses. All meetings of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be
open to the public. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall keep minutes of its
proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon every question, or if absent
or failing to vote, indicating such fact and shall also keep records of its
examinations and other official actions. The concurring vote of four members of
the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be necessary to reverse any order,
requirement, decision, or determination of the Zoning Officer or to decide in
favor of the applicant on any matter which is authorized by this ordinance to
render a decision. Every rule, regulation, every amendment or repeal thereof,
and every order, requirement, decision or determination of the Zoning Board of
Appeals shall immediately be filed in the Office of the Zoning Board of Appeals
and shall be a public record. In the performance of its duties, the Zoning
Board of Appeals may incur such expenditures as shall be authorized by the City
Council. Any member who misses three consecutive meetings will be replaced
after being notified in writing by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1799, passed 7-7-21)
EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD
§ 33.70 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this subchapter, the terms defined in ILCS Ch. 50, Act 750, § 2
et seq. have the meanings ascribed to them in those paragraphs.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95)
§ 33.71 CREATION OF AN EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD FOR THE CITY.
   There is hereby created a body politic and corporate to be known as the
Emergency Telephone System Board of the City of Marseilles. The Board is
constituted a public instrumentality of the city and the exercise by the Board
of the powers conferred by this subchapter shall be deemed and held to be the
performance of an essential public function.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95)
§ 33.72 BOARD MEMBERSHIP; GENERAL.
   (A)   The Mayor, with the approval of the City Council, shall appoint the
members of the Emergency Telephone System Board, whose terms of office shall
commence from the date of appointment.
   (B)   The Board shall consist of seven members.
   (C)   On creation of the Board, initial appointments to the Board shall be
as follows: two members for two year terms; two members for three year terms;
one member for a four year term. Thereafter, whenever a vacancy occurs by
reason of the expiration of the term of any member, the Mayor, with the
approval of the City Council, shall appoint a member to the Board for a term of
three years.
   (D)   Members of the Board shall hold office until their successors are
appointed and may serve more than one successive term.
   (E)   Whenever a vacancy on the Board shall occur as a result of
resignation, death, or any other reason other than expiration of the term of a
member, the Mayor, with the approval of the City Council, shall appoint a
member to complete the term of vacancy.
   (F)   Members of the Board shall receive no compensation for their services
but shall be reimbursed for their actual and necessary expenses.
   (G)   Removal from the Board by the Mayor shall be for cause and only with
the concurrence of the City Council.
   (H)   The Board shall determine by-laws consistent with the purposes of this
section subject to approval of the City Council.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 1025, passed 11-15-00)
§ 33.73 POWERS OF THE BOARD.
   The Emergency Telephone System Board may exercise the following powers under
this section provided, however, that in no event shall the Board encumber city
funds or incur city debt or liability except as provided herein:
   (A)   Planning a 9-1-1 system.
   (B)   Coordinating and supervising the implementation, up-grading or
maintenance of the system, including the establishment of equipment
specifications and coding systems.
   (C)   Receiving monies from the surcharge imposed under Ordinance No. 832,
and from any other source, for deposit into the Emergency Telephone System
Fund.
   (D)   Authorizing all disbursements from the fund, subject to ratification
and approval by the City Council.
   (E)   Hiring, on a temporary basis, any staff necessary for the
implementation or upgrade of the system; provided, however, all legal services,
whether on a temporary basis or otherwise, shall be provided and rendered
solely and exclusively by the City Attorney.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 965, passed 4-7-99)
§ 33.74 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM FUND; EXPENDITURES.
   All monies received by the Emergency Telephone System Board pursuant to the
surcharge imposed under Ordinance No. 832 shall be deposited into an Emergency
Telephone System Fund. The City Treasurer shall be custodian of the fund. All
interest accruing on the fund shall remain in the fund. No expenditures may be
made from such fund except upon the direction of the Board by resolution passed
by a majority of all members of the Board. Expenditures may be made only to pay
for the costs associated with the following:
   (A)   The design of the Emergency Telephone System.
   (B)   The coding of an initial Master Street Address Guide data base, and
update and maintenance thereof.
   (C)   The repayment of any monies advanced for the implementation of the
system.
   (D)   The charges for Automatic Number Identification and Automatic Location
Identification equipment, and maintenance, replacement and update thereof.
   (E)   The non-recurring charges related to installation of the Emergency
Telephone System and the ongoing network charges.
   (F)   Other products and services necessary for the implementation, upgrade
and maintenance of the system, including costs attributable directly to the
construction, leasing or maintenance of any building, or facility or the cost
of personnel attributable directly to the operation of the system; however, the
cost attributable directly to the operation of the Emergency Telephone System
shall not include the cost of public safety agency personnel who are and
equipment that is dispatched in response to emergency calls.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95; Am. Ord. 965, passed 4-7-99)
§ 33.75 INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   The Emergency Telephone System Board, without further City Council approval,
may invest any funds held by it pursuant to this section in:
   (A)   Any obligations which as to principal and interest constitute direct
obligations of or are unconditionally guaranteed by the government;
   (B)   Obligations of the Federal National Mortgage Association;
   (C)   Obligations of the Federal Intermediate Credit Banks;
   (D)   Obligations of Federal Banks for Cooperatives;
   (E)   Obligations of Federal Land Banks;
   (F)   Obligations of Federal Home Loan Banks;
   (G)   Obligations of the Federal Financing Bank;
   (H)   Time certificates of deposit authorized under state or federal law;
   (I)   Any other investments to the extent then permitted by Illinois law.
Any such securities may be purchased at the offering or market price thereof at
the time of such purchase.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95)
§ 33.76 POWERS CONFERRED AS ADDITIONAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL; LIMITATIONS IMPOSED;
EFFECT.
   The powers conferred by this section are in addition and supplemental to,
and the limitations imposed by this section shall not affect the powers
conferred by law or any other ordinance.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95)
§ 33.77 PECUNIARY INTEREST OF MEMBERS OR EMPLOYEES OF THE BOARD; PROHIBITION;
DISCLOSURE.
   (A)   Any member of the Emergency Telephone System Board who owns or
controls any interest direct or indirect in any property included in the "911
system" or under this section shall disclose the same in writing to the Board
and such disclosure shall be entered upon the minute book of the Board.
   (B)   No member of the Board shall vote or act on any project in which said
member holds an interest.
   (C)   If the City Council determines that any Board member has acquired an
interest that is adverse to the best interests of the city, the City Council
may require said member to divest himself of said property or interest, or take
what other steps are necessary to assure compliance with this section.
(Ord. 838, passed 4-19-95)
BOARD OF POLICE COMMISSIONERS
§ 33.80 CREATION; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby created a Board of Police Commissioners as contemplated
under Article 10 Division 2.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (ILCS Ch. 65, Act
5, §§ 10-2.1-1 et seq.). The Board of Police Commissioners is hereby created to
provide for the hiring, promotion and discipline of city police officers.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.81 CHIEF, CAPTAIN, LIEUTENANT, AND PART TIME OFFICERS.
   (A)   The Chief of Police shall be appointed and subject to discipline by
the City Council. The Captain shall be appointed by the Chief of Police subject
to the approval of the Commissioner of Public Health and Safety. The Captain is
subject to discipline and removal by the Chief subject to the approval of the
Commissioner of Public Health and Safety. The position of Lieutenant shall be
appointed by the Chief and Commissioner of Public Health and Safety from the
top three candidates identified from a list provided by the Board of Police
Commissioners. Up to two Lieutenants may be appointed. The Lieutenant shall be
subject to discipline by the Board of Police Commissioners. The position of
Sergeant shall be appointed by Chief and Commissioner of Public Health and
Safety, from the top three candidates identified from a list provided by the
Board of Police Commissioners. Up to two Sergeants may be appointed. The
Sergeant shall be subject to discipline by the Board of Police Commissioners
unless they are members of a collective bargaining unit with an agreement that
states otherwise. A Sergeant may be a member of a collective bargaining unit
due to the lack of supervisory duties held by the more superior officers
identified above. If an active member of the Police Department is appointed
Chief of Police, Captain or Lieutenant prior to being eligible to retire on
pension and thereafter loses the appointment as Chief of Police, Captain or
Lieutenant, such person shall be considered as on furlough from the rank they
held immediately prior to appointment as Chief and their position shall revert
to and be established in such prior rank and thereafter be entitled to all the
benefits and emoluments of such prior rank without regard as to whether a
vacancy then exists in such rank.
   (B)   Part time officers employed by the city shall not be subject to Police
Commission rules.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11; Am. Ord. 1479, passed 6-6-12)
§ 33.82 QUALIFICATIONS AND AFFIDAVIT.
   Each potential application for appointment as a Police Commission Board
Member shall execute an affidavit under oath indicating they satisfy the
following qualifications:
   (A)   Affiant does not hold an office with the City of Marseilles and is not
related either by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin to any
elected official of city;
   (B)   Affiant has not been convicted of a felony under the laws of this
state or any comparable laws of any other state or the United States;
   (C)   Affiant is a registered voter of the city with a disclosed party
affiliation as defined in ILCS Ch. 10, Act 5, §§ 10-2.1-1 et seq., or of any
state or national political party. No more than two members of the Board of
Police Commissioners shall belong to the same political party existing in the
municipality at the time of the appointment;
   (D)   Affiant may not be employed by, or hold an appointed or elected office
of the city while serving as a member of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners;
   (F)   Affiant is not interested directly or indirectly, in any contract,
work or business of the municipality or sale of any article of goods, services,
or contract of any kind to or with the city; and
   (G)   Affiant is not a purchaser or seller of any real property to the
municipality or involved in the purchase or sale of real estate for delinquent
real estate taxes within the city.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.83 APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE; REMOVAL OF MEMBER.
   (A)   Appointment and term of office. The Mayor, with the consent of the
City Council, shall appoint three members to the Board of Police Commissioners.
For the first appointed Board, one of the members shall be appointed to serve
until the end of the then current municipal year, another to serve until the
end of the municipal year next ensuing, and the third to serve until the end of
the municipal year second next ensuing. After the initial appointments, terms
of office shall be for three years. Notwithstanding the above, every member
shall serve until their successor is appointed and has qualified. Vacancies on
the Board of Police Commissioners shall be filled by the Mayor with the consent
of the City Council. Upon appointment, members shall take an oath of office.
   (B)   Removal of member. Members shall not be subject to removal, except for
cause upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within 30 days
in his or her own defense, before a regular meeting of the City Council. A
majority vote of the City Council shall be required to remove any such member
from office.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.84 COMPENSATION.
   Absent further action by the City Council, member of the Board shall serve
without compensation.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.85 OFFICERS OF BOARD.
   The Board Members shall elect from their membership a chairman and secretary
to serve during the municipal fiscal year. The Secretary of the Board shall
have all the powers and authority and shall perform such duties as are provided
and set forth in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 10-2.1-1 et seq. including:
   (A)   Keep the minutes of the Board’s proceedings;
   (B)   Be the custodian of all records pertaining to the business of the
Board;
   (C)   Keep a record of all examinations held;
   (D)   Perform all other duties the Board prescribes; and
   (E)   The Board may, upon approval of the Mayor, utilize the staff and
facilities at City Hall.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.86 RULES, POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD.
   A majority of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of all
business. The Board shall have all the powers and authority, and shall perform
such duties as are provided and set forth in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 10-2.1-1 et
seq.. The Board shall make rules to carry out their duties under ILCS Ch. 65,
Act 5, §§ 10-2.1-1 et seq.. A copy of any rules adopted by the Board shall be
provided the City Clerk. No such rule shall be made by the Board to govern the
operation of the Police Department or the conduct of its members.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.87 MINOR DISCIPLINE.
   No rule of the Board of Police Commissioners shall prevent the Chief of the
Police Department from suspending without pay a member of his or her department
for a period of not more than five calendar days, but he or she shall notify
the Board in writing of such suspension. Any officer so suspended may appeal to
the Board of Police Commissioners for a review of the suspension within five
calendar days after such suspension, and upon such appeal, the Board may
sustain the action of the Chief of the Department, may reverse it with
instructions that the officer receive his or her pay for the period involved,
or may suspend the officer for an additional period of not more than 30 days or
discharge him or her, depending upon the facts presented.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.88 ATTORNEY FOR BOARD.
   Unless otherwise determined by the City Council, the City Attorney shall
represent the Board. The Board shall make a request to the City Council for an
additional attorney should any proceeding before the Board reasonably require
such.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
§ 33.89 ANNUAL REPORT; CITY COUNCIL RESPONSIBILITIES TOWARD BOARD.
   (A)   Annual report. Annually, at any time the City Council is working on
their budget, the Board shall submit to the City Council a report of its
activities and an annual budget request.
   (B)   City Council responsibilities toward Board. The City Council shall
provide a suitable room at the City Hall, or larger facility if required, for
the Board of Police Commissioners meetings and examinations and shall provide
adequate funds in the annual appropriation ordinance for the operation of the
Board.
(Ord. 1437, passed 7-6-11)
MIDDLE EAST TRIBUTE BOARD
§ 33.90 CREATION.
   There is hereby created a Middle East Tribute Board.
(Ord. 1328, passed 2-6-08)
§ 33.91 MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Mayor, with the approval of the City Council, shall appoint the
members of the Middle East Tribute Board.
   (B)   The Middle East Tribute Board shall consist of seven members.
   (C)   At the initial meeting of the Middle East Tribute Board, the Board
shall assign initial terms of office for board members as follows: one member
for a one-year term, two members for two-year terms; two members for three-year
terms; two members for four-year terms.
   (D)   After the expiration of the above mentioned initial terms of office,
Board members shall hold office for four-year terms. A Board member may serve
more than one successive term.
   (E)   Appointment of members to the Middle East Tribute Board, whether
arising from expiration of term of office, resignation, death, or any other
reason, shall be made by the Mayor, with the approval of the City Council from
a list of persons nominated by the remaining members of the Middle East Tribute
Board.
   (F)   The majority of the Middle East Tribute Board may remove any member
from their board.
   (G)   Members of the Board shall receive no compensation for their services
but shall be reimbursed for their actual and necessary expenses.
(Ord. 1328, passed 2-6-08)
§ 33.92 RESPONSIBILITIES AND POWERS.
   The Middle East Tribute Board shall:
   (A)   Have charge of the property and assume the duties and responsibilities
of the City of Marseilles as a tenant to the property commonly known as the
Middle East Wall Memorial.
   (B)   As to any events proposed to take place at or about the Middle East
Wall Memorial, act as a liaison between the event organizer, City of
Marseilles, owners of property in the area of the Middle East Wall Memorial,
and other interested parties.
   (C)   Recommend for adoption such ordinances or resolutions to the City
Council as reasonably required by the Middle East Tribute Board to fulfill
their duties and responsibilities.
   (D)   Timely make requests of the appropriate City Commissioner for the
services of city employees and use of city equipment.
   (E)   Report to and work with the City Council on any major events such as
the annual freedom run, and request the services of other representatives of
the city as reasonably required.
   (F)   Establish by-laws.
   (G)   Comply with the Open Meetings Act, Freedom of Information Act and
other general governmental mandates.
(Ord. 1328, passed 2-6-08)
§ 33.93 FINANCES.
   (A)   Annual financial process: The Middle East Tribute Board shall annually
submit a budget contemporaneous in time to the city's budget and appropriation
process. The Board shall submit a financial report to the City Council at least
annually and participate in the annual city audit.
   (B)   The Middle East Tribute Board shall maintain their own financial
accounts and establish financial safeguards as reasonably required by the Mayor
or auditor.
   (C)   The Middle East Tribute Board may solicit donations and collect
receipts from events and use such funds to carry out their responsibilities.
   (D)   In the event the Middle East Tribute Board is dissolved, donated funds
shall be transferred to a not-for-profit corporation having exempt purposes
within the meaning of § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code similar to that
before assumed by the Middle East Tribute Board.
(Ord. 1328, passed 2-6-08)
