GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 52.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   BASIC WATER USER CHARGE. The base amount billed each billing period to every
economic unit which includes, without limitation, costs for radium removal and
IEPA testing
   BOD (BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND). The quantity of oxygen used in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter in five days at 20°C, determined by
standard laboratory test procedures and expressed in mg/l.
   ECONOMIC UNIT. Each dwelling unit* business*, industry, mobile home* located
on a mobile home lot* or other lot, recreational vehicle* located on a
recreational vehicle lot* and any other entity receiving city water and/or
sewer services (*see definition in Marseilles Zoning Ordinance) or where water
and/or sewer services would reasonably be expected. A building, building
complex, mobile home with more than one economic unit shall be considered as
have the number of economic units housed therein regardless of the number of
water meters or sewer connections contained therein the number of economic
units attributed to a campground, or to an owners' association of any planned
development or other form of subdivision designed not for single family homes
but for recreational vehicles where each recreational vehicle that does not
have a city approved water meter (hereinafter camping facility) shall be
determined by the following formula:
      (1)   Formula. The total monthly metered water usage for the camping
facility shall be divided by the average of all water usage in the applicable
geographic area (North or the Illinois River or South of the Illinois River).
Such average shall be determined by the total water usage in the geographic
area (minus the water account of any camping facility) divided by the total
number of water accounts in the geographic area (minus camping facility
accounts).
         (a)   The number of economic units, rounded down to a whole number,
shall be the number of economic units applied to the monthly bill. Such formula
shall be calculated monthly and the calculation shall be included with the
monthly billing. The following is an example of the calculation:
         (b)   Example of formula. 
         If in the month of August a camping facility located North of the
Illinois has a total metered water usage of 4,141 units (414,100 gallons) and
the average water usage of all water users North of the Illinois (except for
the camping facilities) was 51 units (5,100 gallons), the August billing
calculation to determine the number of Economic Units (to be multiplied against
basic charges) would be as follows:
            Camping Facility metered water use:   4,141 units (414,100 gallons)
            Average water use North of Illinois River:   51 units (5,100
gallons)
            Metered usage divided by average:   81.19 economic units
            Units rounded down to whole number:   81 economic units
         Economic Units of 81 multiplied by basic charge of $25.50* = $2,065.50
basic charge to be added to water and sewer usage charges (*in this example,
*$25.50 is combined basic charges for water and sewer North of the Illinois
River).
   MAY. Is permissive.
   PERSON. Any and all persons, natural or artificial including any individual,
partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company,
corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political
subdivision, or any other legal entity or their legal representatives, agents
or assigns.
   POTABLE WATER. Any water used for human or domestic consumption, including,
but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes
or preparing foods.
   REPLACEMENT COSTS. Expenditures for purchasing and installing equipment,
accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of
the sewerage works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such
works were designed and constructed.
   SHALL. Is mandatory.
   SEWERAGE WORKS. All facilities of the city for collecting and pumping sewage
and industrial wastes.
   SURCHARGE. The amount to be paid each billing period by certain public sewer
users in addition to the basic user charge.
   TOTAL WATER CHARGE. The combined amounts of the basic water user charge and
the water user service charge amount billed each billing period to every
economic unit.
   UNIT. A total of 100 gallons of metered water usage.
   WATER VOLUME CHARGE. The amount billed each billing period to every economic
unit based on the volume of water usage which includes, without limitation,
costs of operation, maintenance, and replacement for the sewerage works.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75; Am. Ord. 565, passed 11-28-77; Am. Ord. 1240,
passed 2-15-06; Am. Ord. 1571, passed 4-15-15; Am. Ord. 1619, passed 11-16-16;
Am. Ord. 1708, passed 5-15-19)
§ 52.02 RIGHT OF CITY TO SHUT OFF WATER FOR PURPOSE OF REPAIRS, EXTENSIONS OR
OTHER PURPOSE.
   (A)   The city may, when necessary, without notice, shut the water off in
its mains for the purpose of making repairs or extensions or for other purposes
and no claims shall be made against the city by reason of the breakage of any
service pipe or service cock, or from any other damage that may result from
shutting off water for repairing, laying or re-laying mains, hydrants, or other
connections. The Water and Sewer Department shall give notice of shutting off
water if conditions are such that it is possible to do so.
   (B)   When water is shut off for making repairs in premises having water
heat-coils in heaters, consumers should turn off the water at the basement
shut-off and open a faucet in the hot water pipe and leave it open until water
is turned on, in order to protect piping and fixtures from excessive pressures
from hot water or steam.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75)
§ 52.03 BREAKS IN SERVICE OR FIXTURES.
   The city shall not be held responsible by reason of the breaking of any
service pipe or apparatus, or for failure in the supply of water.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75)
§ 52.04 SUPPLYING WATER TO OTHERS PROHIBITED.
    No consumer shall supply water to other persons, nor suffer them to take it
except by special permission from the Superintendent of Water and Sewer or his
agents. Where such permission is granted, the owner of the service from which
the water is taken shall be responsible for payment of the total amount of the
bill plus an additional monthly minimum water and sewer charge for each further
residential unit provided water from the customer’s service.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75; Am. Ord. 1308, passed 12-5-07 ) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 52.05 USE OF FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (A)   No person except members of the Department of Streets and Public
Improvements of the city, or officers of employees of the Water and Sewer
Department acting in the regular performance of their duties, shall open any
hydrant belonging to the department at any time without a permit in writing
signed by the Commissioner of Public Property.
   (B)   Any person or entity wishing to purchase water in bulk from the city
by tapping directly into a hydrant shall be required to make application to the
city for this service. A charge of $30 shall include a hook up to a city water
meter, a water shut off valve and up to 150 feet of water hose. There shall
also be the usual water service charge, based on the city’s current water and
sewer rate for every 100 gallons of water used. Use of city fire hydrants shall
only be permitted on city business days between 7:00 a.m. and 2:30 p.m.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75; Am. Ord. 1112, passed 7-2-03; Am. Ord. 1543, passed
6-4-14) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 52.06 INFORMATION FURNISHED TO PLUMBERS; ACCURACY NOT GUARANTEED.
   Such information as may be obtained from the records, maps, employees, and
the like, of the Water and Sewer Department relative to the location of water
mains, service pipes, will be furnished to licensed plumbers and interested
parties; but the Department does not guarantee the accuracy of the same.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75)
§ 52.07 DELINQUENT WATER OR SEWER BILL, TAX OR SERVICE ON PREMISES PREREQUISITE
TO PURCHASING PREMISES.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of any person about to purchase any premises
within the corporate limits of the city, or of any mortgagee, trustee or lien
claimant holding any mortgage, trust deed or lien against any premises within
the city, to first ascertain from the office of the City Clerk as to any
delinquent water or sewer bill, tax, rate, rent or service that may have
accrued or be against said premises, before purchasing the premises or
instituting proceedings foreclosing said mortgage, trust deed, or lien and to
notify the City Clerk in writing as to his intentions of purchasing said
property or foreclosing said mortgage, trust deed or lien, and 24 hours notice
shall be deemed sufficient notice under this section.
   (B)   In addition to any other remedy provided herein for the enforcement or
collection of any water or sewer tax, rate of rent, all such rates or rents
shall be a lien upon the premises and real estate upon and for which the same
is used or supplied. Such liens shall attach when the water or sewer bill
becomes delinquent, which is hereby declared to be 15 days after the due date
of payment as set forth on said bill, and may be enforced together with the
cost and penalties by foreclosure in equity in any court having jurisdiction in
the same manner and with like force and effect as the foreclosure of liens of
mortgages and trust deed.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75)
§ 52.08 USE OF GROUNDWATER AS A POTABLE WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED.
   (A)   Use of groundwater as a potable water supply is prohibited except for
such uses or methods in existence before the effective date of this section.
The use of, or attempted use of, groundwater from within the corporate limits
of the city, as a potable water supply, by the installation or drilling of
wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited. This prohibition does not
include the city.
   (B)    Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined
according to the Uniform Fine Schedule in §
10.99.
   (C)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to enter into a memorandum
of understanding with the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency ("Illinois
EPA") in which the city assumes responsibility for tracking all sites that have
received no further remediation determinations from the Illinois EPA, notifying
the Illinois EPA of changes to this section and taking certain precautions when
siting public potable water supply wells.
(Ord. 1240, passed 2-15-06; Am. Ord. 1326, passed 2-20-08 )
SERVICE CHARGES AND USE REGULATIONS
§ 52.15 APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE.
   (A)   A written application for water services must be completed and
delivered to City Hall. The application must include evidence of ownership of
the property in question such as by a copy of a deed, title policy, or property
insurance policy. The applicant must present with the application appropriate
identification. When submitting their application, applicant(s) must present
adequate identification. Identification must show the applicant’s name, date of
birth, and residential or business address and no less than one form of
photographic identification such as driver’s license or state identification
card. A business entity must provide proof of the business entity’s existence
and all principals of the business must be identified on the application. No
less than one principal of the business must present the application and such
principal will need to provide adequate identification and proof of his or her
principal relationship with the business entity. No social security numbers or
tax identification numbers will be requested in the application process. Water
bills will not be sent to tenants. Owners will receive bills for all service
accounts at only one mailing address.
   (B)   No owner seeking to establish a new city water and sewer account,
shall be given water service until any and all delinquent water and sewer
charges shall have been paid in full. A charge of $35 will be made for turning
on water and renewing service.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75; Am. Ord. 1356, passed 11-5-08 )
§ 52.16 DEPOSITS; RESPONSIBILITY FOR PAYMENT FOR WATER SERVICE.
   (A)   A deposit of $75 is required at time of application for water and
sewer service.
   (B)   Said deposit may be refunded after one year, provided all fees and
charges have been timely paid in full. It shall remain the responsibility of
the person tendering the deposit to request a refund of deposits by submitting
a written request to the City Clerk.
   (C)   The owner applicant is always responsible for payment of services
regardless if the owner provides the bills to tenant for payment and regardless
if any deposit was refunded.
   (D)   No refunds or discounts on water rentals shall be made on account of
the premises having been vacant or no water used unless water has been shut off
by the Water and Sewer Department upon written request of the owner or
consumer.
   (E)   An administrative fee of $25 shall be imposed at the time each new
account is opened or modified.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75; Am. Ord. 693, passed 12-30-85; Am. Ord. 708, passed
12-17-86; Am. Ord. 750, passed 7-3-90; Am. Ord. 1241, passed 2-15-06; Am. Ord.
1345, passed 8-20-08; Am. Ord. 1356, passed 11-5-08)
§ 52.17 CHARGE FOR WATER SERVICE.
   (A)   There shall be and there are hereby established a total water charge
for the use of and for the service supplied by the city water works which shall
consist of a basic water user charge and a water volume charge. Total water
charge shall be determined by the amount of revenue funds required to operate
and maintain the city water works and to provide a fund for the repair and/or
replacement of component parts of said water works for each fiscal year. Said
charges shall also be determined by geographic location north and south of the
Illinois River.
   (B)   The water volume charge for North of the Illinois River is $0.47 per
each unit (unit is 100 gallons) or fractions thereof. Effective August 1,2021
the volume charge north of the Illinois River shall be $0.485 per unit. On May
1, 2022 and thereafter each year on May 1 the volume charge shall increase in
an amount of $0.015 per each unit.
   (C)   The water volume charge for South of the Illinois River is $0.425.
Effective August 1, 2021 the volume charge South of the Illinois River shall be
$0.44 per unit. On May 1, 2022 and thereafter each year on May 1 the volume
charge shall increase in an amount of $0.015 per each unit.
      (1)   The volume water charges shall commence and be assessed against
each economic unit upon a water line from the economic unit being connected to
a city water main.
      (2)   The volume water charges may be shut off upon requesting a
termination of water service. (Notice, however, the basic water charges
continue, unless the City Council passes a resolution to terminate charges or
unless the lateral water line serving property from the city water main is
removed.)
   (D)   The purpose of the basic water user charge is to charge a base amount
each billing period to every economic unit which receives or is capable of
receiving city water to cover the basic charges of maintaining the water system
which includes, without limitation, ongoing infrastructure costs, radium
removal and IEPA testing. The basic water user charges shall commence and be
assessed against each economic unit upon a water line from the economic unit
being connected to a city water main. The charges continue until there is no
longer a connection from the economic unit to the city water main, or if the
City Council has passed a resolution to terminate charges. A temporary shut off
of water shall not terminate basic water charges.
      (1)   North of the Illinois River, the basic water user charge is $8.75.
Effective August 1, 2021, the charge shall be $11. Effective May 1, 2022, the
charge shall be $12.
      (2)   South of the Illinois River, the basic water user charge is $34.
(Ord. 549, passed 12-22-75; Am. Ord. 563, passed 10-17-77; Am. Ord. 624, passed
5-20-81; Am. Ord. 651, passed 1-5-83; Am. Ord. 669, passed 12-15-83; Am. Ord.
693, passed 12-30-85; Am. Ord. 750, passed 7-3-90; Am. Ord. 850, passed 9-6-95;
Am. Ord. 929, passed 3-11-98; Am. Ord. 968, passed 6-2-99; Am. Ord. 1016,
passed 7-19-00; Am. Ord. 1125, passed 9-3-03; Am. Ord. 1449, passed - -11; Am.
