GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 112.01 INTERPRETATION.
   This chapter shall be liberally construed to the end that the health, safety
and welfare of the residents of the city shall be protected and temperance in
the consumption of alcoholic liquor shall be fostered and promoted.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (A)   Unless the context shall otherwise require, terms used in this chapter
shall have the definitions given in the ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, Art. I, as amended
from time to time. Where not otherwise qualified, the term LICENSE or LICENSEE
wherever used in this chapter means a license or licensee of the city under
this chapter.
   (B)   The Mayor shall be the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and the terms
MAYOR and LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER shall be used interchangeably in
this chapter.
   (C)   BEER GARDEN shall be defined as an open, unroofed or partially roofed
area where beer and other alcoholic beverages are served or consumed by the
general public.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 778, passed 7-1-92)
§ 112.03 PEDDLING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the city.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.04 DRINKING IN PUBLIC PLACES; TRANSPORTATION OR POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC
LIQUOR.
   (A)   No person shall, within the city, drink any alcoholic liquor in any
public street, public alley, public park or other public place, in or upon any
vehicle, commonly used for the transportation of passengers or in or upon any
depot, platform or waiting room of any public place or in any passenger coach,
bus or at any public gathering.
   (B)   No person shall transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor
in or upon any public street, public alley, public park or other public place
except in the original package and with the seal unbroken.
   (C)   No person under the age of 21 may possess or consume alcoholic liquor
within the corporate limits of the city; except, however, the consumption or
possession by a person under 21 years of age of alcoholic liquor in the
performance of a religious service or ceremony, or the consumption or
possession by a person under 21 years of age under the direct supervision and
approval of the parents or parent or those persons standing in loco parentis of
such person under 21 years of age in the privacy of a home, is not prohibited
by this section.
   (D)   (1)   A person under the age of 21 who wrongfully possesses or
consumes alcoholic liquor in violation of division (C) above in the case of a
first violation shall be fined no less than $200 and no more than $750 plus
court costs.
      (2)   In the case of a second violation committed within five years of
the same particular provision, the defendant shall be fined no less than $350
and no more than $750 plus court costs.
      (3)   In the case of a third or further violation committed within five
years of the same particular provision, the defendant shall be fined $750 plus
court costs.
      (4)   Each act of violation and each day upon which a violation occurs
constitutes a separate offense.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 1005, passed 6-7-00; Am. Ord. 1326,
passed 2-20-08 ) Penalty, see §
112.99
LICENSING
§ 112.15 CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES; FEES.
   (A)    Licenses to sell alcoholic liquor shall be designated as follows:
      (1)   Class “A” Retail License. The annual license fee for a Class “A”
license, for the sale of alcoholic liquors to be consumed either on or off the
premises, shall be the sum of $800, which fee may be paid semiannually, in
payments of $400 each on May 1 and November 1.
      (2)   Class “B” Club License.
         (a)   The annual license fee for a Class “B” license, for the sale of
alcoholic liquors in a club, as herein defined, and to be sold and consumed on
the premises by the members of such club and the invited guests of such
members, when such guest is personally attended by a member, shall be the sum
of $200, which license fee may be paid semiannually in payments of $100 each,
on May 1 and November 1.
         (b)   A CLUB is hereby defined to be an association of individuals or
a not-for-profit corporation, organized for a fraternal, benevolent, civic or
religious purpose; a club shall not be open to the public and the sale of
alcoholic liquor shall be limited to members of said club and their personal
guests.
      (3)   Class “C” Retail Package Liquor License. The annual license fee for
a Class “C” license, for the sale of alcoholic liquor on the premises, but not
to be consumed on the premises, shall be the sum of $600, which license fee may
be paid semiannually, in payments of $300 each, on May 1 and November 1.
      (4)   Class “D” Restaurant License.
         (a)   The annual license fee for a Class “D” license, for the sale of
alcoholic liquor to be consumed solely on the premises where the sale and
consumption of food is the primary business conducted therein, shall be the sum
of $500, which license fee may be paid semiannually, in payments of $250 each,
on May 1 and November 1.
         (b)   It shall be unlawful for a licensee holding a Class “D” retail
license to sell alcoholic liquor except to a patron who is purchasing or
consuming food on the premises.
      (5)   Class “E” Beer Garden Supplemental License.  
         (a)   The annual supplemental license fee for a Class “E” license, for
the sale of alcoholic liquor in a beer garden, as defined in §
112.01, and to be sold and consumed on the premises by the public shall be the
additional sum of $200, which license fee may be paid semi-annually, in
payments of $100 each, on May 1 and November 1.
         (b)   It shall be unlawful for a licensee holding a Class “E” beer
garden license to hold supplemental beer garden license without also holding a
valid Class “A”, “B” or “D” liquor license.
      (6)   Class “F” Outdoor Seasonal Event Retail Liquor License. The annual
license fee for a Class “F” license, for the sale of alcoholic liquors to be
consumed on the premises within a designated outdoor area during a seasonal
period of operation. The sale of alcoholic liquors shall not occur at any time
between after dusk and before dawn, nor shall alcoholic liquors be sold before
8:00 a.m. on Sundays. No packaged liquor sales are allowed. The fee shall be
the sum of $300, which shall be paid at the beginning of the season.
   (B)   Sanitary conditions. All premises, whether wholesale or retail, and
licensed under this chapter, shall be kept in sanitary condition and shall be
open to inspection by the Health Officer, Chief of Police and any other
authorized official of the city.
   (C)   Nonpayment of fee. Any licensee, or applicant for license, who does
not pay the required fee at the time required by this chapter, shall be charged
a $100 late fee, which amount shall be payable prior to the issuance or renewal
of any license hereunder.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 1493, passed 10-3-12; Am. Ord. 1516,
passed 9-4-13; Am. Ord. 1740, passed 2-5-20) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.16 LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF LICENSES.
   The City Council shall have the right and power to limit the number of
licenses of each class to be issued within the corporate limits of the city and
also may limit the number of each class in any locality or section or portion
of the city in accordance with the public interest.
   (A)   The number of Class “A” Retail Licenses, authorized to be issued
within the corporate limits of the city shall not exceed 13, with no more than
eight of those licenses being located on Main Street.
   (B)   The number of Class “C” Package Licenses, authorized to be issued
within the corporate limits of the city shall not exceed six.
   (C)   One Class “F” Outdoor Seasonal Event Retail Liquor Licenses is
authorized to be issued by the Liquor Commissioner within the corporate limits
of the city and additional licenses may be isued as necessary from time to time
by the City Council.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 722, passed 12-2-87; Am. Ord. 942,
passed 7-1-98; Am. Ord. 1261, passed 11-1-06; Am. Ord. 1440, passed 5-4-11; Am.
Ord. 1493, passed 10-3-12; Am. Ord. 1494, passed 10-3-12; Am. Ord. 1516, passed
9-4-13)
§ 112.17 PERSONS INELIGIBLE TO LICENSE.
   No liquor license shall be issued to:
   (A)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community;
   (B)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States;
   (C)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal law or
the laws of the State of Illinois, or the laws of any other state;
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of a crime or misdemeanor opposed to
decency and morality;
   (E)   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for
cause;
   (F)   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for a license upon a first application;
   (G)   A co-partnership, unless all of the members of such co-partnership
shall be qualified to obtain a license;
   (H)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than 5% of the stock
of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder.
   (I)   A corporation unless it is incorporated in the state, or unless it is
a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporate
Act to transact business in the state;
   (J)   A person whose place of business in conducted by a manager or agent
unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required for the
licensee;
   (K)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor
subsequent to January 31, 1934, or shall have forfeited his bond to appear in
court to answer charges for any such violation;
   (L)   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought,
or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is
to be issued;
   (M)   Any law enforcing public official, Mayor or member of the City
Council; and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly
or indirectly in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor;
   (N)   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated
by the licensee;
   (O)   Any person, association or corporation not eligible for a state retail
liquor dealer's license.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.18 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (A)   No person shall sell or offer for sale or possess with intention to
sell within the corporate limits of the city, any alcoholic liquor without
having first obtained a license to do so as provided in this chapter, and
having paid to the City Clerk the license fee for such license. No person shall
sell or offer for sale in the city any alcoholic liquor in violation of any
provision of this chapter or any provision of the Illinois Liquor Control Act.
   (B)   The requirement that a city license be procured shall not apply to
physicians, dentists, pharmacists, hospitals or churches when these persons or
institutions possess or dispense alcoholic liquor in accordance with the
provisions of the ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 2-1, as amended from time to time.
   (C)   No person shall hereafter keep, maintain, conduct or operate any beer
garden without first obtaining a license therefor.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 778, passed 7-1-92) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.19 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; CONTENTS.
   (A)   Application for a liquor license shall be made to the Mayor in writing
upon blanks prepared and furnished by the city, signed by the applicant, if an
individual, or by at least two members of a partnership, if the applicant is a
partnership, or if the applicant is a corporation, then by the president and
secretary thereof, verified by oath or affidavit of the signers, and shall
contain the following information and statement:
      (1)   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a co-partnership, the persons entitled to share in
the profits thereof, and in the case of a corporation, for profit, or a club,
the date of the incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the
names and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority interest
of the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the
name and address of such person;
      (2)   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization;
      (3)   The character of business of the applicant; and in case of a
corporation the objects for which it was formed;
      (4)   The length of time that applicant has been in business of that
character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was
issued;
      (5)   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application is made;
      (6)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license, including both street address and
legal description of premises;
      (7)   A statement whether applicant has made similar application for a
similar or other license on premises other than described in this application;
      (8)   A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony
and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter of thing
contained in this chapter ar any ordinance or statute;
      (9)   Whether a previous license by any state or political subdivision
thereof or by the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons
therefore;
      (10)   The date of incorporation, if an Illinois corporation, or the date
of becoming qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact
business in Illinois, if a foreign corporation;
      (11)   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of
the State of Illinois or of the United States or any ordinance of the city in
the conduct of his business;
      (12)   That he has not received or borrowed money or anything else of
value, and that he will not receive or borrow money or anything else of value,
except as permitted by ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, directly or indirectly from any
manufacturer, importing distributor or distributor;
      (13)   A statement that the applicant, upon the issuance of the license
for which this application is made, will conduct the business continuously
during the term of said license, and upon the cessation of business for a
period of 60 consecutive days will surrender said license to the city.
   (B)   The application, addressed to the mayor as aforesaid, shall be filed
with the City Clerk with the appropriate fees as set forth herein.
   (C)   The Clerk shall deliver said fee to the City Treasurer for deposit in
the General Corporate Fund and present the application to the Mayor within
seven calendar days after the Clerk receives the application, except if the
application is one for a full year's license, then the filing procedure will be
the same as used in “Renewal of License” as set forth herein.
   (D)   (1)   Application for a supplemental beer garden license shall be made
in the same manner by an applicant who either currently holds a Class “A”, “B”
or “D” liquor license or has made a contemporaneous application for a Class
“A”, “B” or “D” license.
      (2)   A person licensed under this chapter shall be entitled to such
privilege, upon the payment of such additional fee, provided, however, that
where one-half of the buildings wholly within a distance of 300 feet from the
property boundaries of such persons licensed premises are used for residence or
apartment house purposes, such person shall first obtain and file with the City
Clerk the written consent of a majority of the legal voters residing within
such area. It shall be the duty of the city to cause an investigation to be
made and to endorse on the application for such privilege whether or not one-
half of the buildings wholly within such area are used for residence or
apartment house purposes.
      (3)   A majority of the legal voters residing within a distance of 300
feet from the property boundaries of a location, place or premises licensed
pursuant to this division (D) may file a petition with the City Clerk
requesting the Mayor, as Local Liquor Control Commissioner, to revoke the
privilege which allows for the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquor in any
unenclosed or partially enclosed area on the property or adjacent to the
property of an existing licenses location, place or premises. Upon the filing
of such a petition the Mayor shall hold a hearing thereon pursuant to
appropriate statutory and ordinance procedure.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 778, passed 7-1-92)
§ 112.20 REJECTION OR APPROVAL OF APPLICATION.
   The Mayor shall investigate the statements in each application, and within
30 days after such application has been made to the City Clerk, as aforesaid,
the Mayor shall either approve or reject such application. In the event the
Mayor approves such application and grants such license applied for, the Clerk
shall issue such license to such applicant upon the payment in advance of the
license fee required and the execution of such penal bond as aforesaid.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.21 TERM OF LICENSES; PRORATION OF FEES.
   Each such license issued hereunder shall terminate at midnight on April 30,
next following the date of issuance. In the event an application is made for
the issuance of a license after May 1, but prior to November 1, the fee to be
paid shall be the same as if the license is issued May 1. In the event an
application is made for the issuance of a license on November 1 or thereafter
only one-half of the annual fee shall be paid.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.22 REFUND OF FEE FOR DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be returned to
the applicant.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.23 PERSONAL NATURE OF LICENSE; RESTRICTIONS ON TRANSFER.
   (A)   (1)   A license issued hereunder shall be purely a personal privilege,
valid until midnight of April 30 following its issuance, unless sooner revoked
as herein provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject
to the attachment, garnishment or execution or subject to be encumbered or
hypothecated.
      (2)   Such license shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate
devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that
executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the
trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consist in part
of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale of alcoholic liquor
under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the
deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of such decedent, or
such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license but not
longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such
licensee.
      (3)   No refund shall be made of any portion of the licensee fee paid,
but in the event the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such
license in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter prior to November
1, he shall not be required to pay the second half of the annual fee as
provided for herein.
   (B)   A license may be transferred by a licensee to another party but only
if the transferee files a proper application and bond and meets all the
requirements for a license as herein set forth. All requests for transfer must
be in writing and be approved by the Mayor. The fee for such transfer shall be
as in the case of an original application for license.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.24 CHANGE OF LOCATION.
   All licenses issued pursuant to the authority of this chapter shall permit
the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application
and license. Once a license has been granted for a particular premises, the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner, upon application by the licensee, may
endorse upon the license permission to abandon the premises therein described
and to remove the license to another premises approved by him and described in
the endorsement. The application for transfer shall be in writing, under oath
and shall fully describe the premises. The reasons for transfer shall be given
and it shall be shown that the new premises comply in all respects with the
requirements of this chapter and the statutes of the state. If the bond
previously filed by the licensee does not apply to the new location, a new bond
will have to be filed and approved pursuant to the terms of this chapter.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.25 POSTING LICENSES.
   Every person licensed under this chapter shall immediately post and keep
posted while in force, in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises, the
license so issued. Whenever such license shall be lost or destroyed, a
duplicate in lieu thereof shall be issued by the City Clerk, upon payment of a
fee of $15.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 112.26 RENEWAL OF LICENSES.
   (A)   Applications for renewal of liquor licenses shall be filed with the
City Clerk on or before the last Monday in March each year. The Clerk shall
report the names of all applicants for renewals of licenses to the Mayor at the
first regular April meeting of the City Council of such year, together with the
location of the place of business of each applicant and the amount of license
fees payable upon the renewal of such licenses, and whether or not any written
complaint has been filed as to the manner in which any applicant for such
renewal of a license has carried on the business authorized thereby.
   (B)   All applications for renewals of licenses shall be referred by the
Clerk to the Mayor, as in the case of applications for original licenses, and
procedure for renewal thereof shall be as in the case of applications for
original licenses.
   (C)   Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided
he is then qualified to receive a license and the premise for which such
renewal license is sought are suitable for such purpose; and provided, further
that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a
vested right which shall in any case prevent the City Council from decreasing
the number of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.27 (RESERVED.)
§ 112.28 NON-USE OF LICENSE.
   In the event a licensee does not use his license to operate an establishment
for the sale of liquor for a period of 60 consecutive days, the Mayor shall
revoke the license and require its immediate surrender. The licensee shall not
be entitled to a refund of any portion of the licensee fee paid, but if the
revocation occurs before November 1 he shall not be required to pay the second
half of the annual fee as required hereby.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.29 SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   Any license issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the
Mayor (Local Liquor Control Commissioner) for any one or more of the following
reasons:
   (A)   Violation of the laws of the State of Illinois or of any of the
provisions of this chapter;
   (B)   The making of any false statement as to a material fact in application
for a license; or
   (C)   Permitting any illegal, disorderly or immoral practices upon licensed
premises.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.30 ISSUANCE OF TEMPORARY LICENSES; LIMITATION FEE.
   (A)   The Mayor shall have the power to issue temporary licenses for the
sale at retail of beer only at any banquet, picnic, fair, game, bazaar or
similar assembly. Such temporary permits shall be only issued to a benevolent,
charitable, religious or civic organization organized not for pecuniary profit
and shall be for a period not to exceed three days.
   (B)   No more than two such temporary permits shall be granted to any such
organization in any one period of seven days.
   (C)   Such permit shall not permit the sale of alcoholic liquor in any place
where the same is otherwise prohibited by law.
   (D)   The fee shall be $150 for each temporary permit.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 1450, passed - -11)
§ 112.31 RECORD OF LICENSE TO BE KEPT.
   The Mayor shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all such
licenses issued by him and shall furnish the City Clerk, City Treasurer and
Chief of Police with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance of any new license or
the revocation of any existing license, the Mayor shall notify each of the said
officers thereof within one week of such action. (Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
STANDARDS OF OPERATION
§ 112.40 SALE TO MINORS, DRUNKARDS OR SPENDTHRIFTS.
   (A)   Sales of alcoholic liquor are subject to all prohibitions and
penalties set forth in the ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, §§ 6-16 and 6-20 as amended
from time to time.
   (B)   Any person under the age of 21 years who misrepresents his or her age
for the purpose of purchasing and receiving alcoholic liquors in any tavern, or
other place in the city where alcoholic liquors are sold, shall upon conviction
thereof be fined as set forth herein
   (C)   Every place in the city where alcoholic liquor is sold shall display
in a prominent place, a printed card which shall read substantially as follows:
“WARNING
Persons Under 21 Years of Age
Your are subject to a fine up to  $750  under Ordinance of the City of
Marseilles if you purchase alcoholic liquor or misrepresent your age for the
purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor.”
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82 ; Am. Ord. 1326, passed 2-20-08 ) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.41 UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW OF PREMISES.
   The provisions of ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § , as amended from time to time,
shall apply to premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption
on the premises is licensed.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.42 ACCESS TO DWELLING QUARTERS FROM LICENSED PREMISES.
   There shall be no access from licensed premises to dwelling quarters except
as permitted under ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 6-13, as amended from time to time.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.43 LOCATION RESTRICTIONS.
   No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor
within 100 feet of any church, school, hospital, home for aged or indigent
persons or for veterans, their surviving spouses or children, or any military
or naval stations; provided, that this provision shall not apply to hotels
offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food
shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal
business.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 892, passed 2-5-97)
§ 112.44 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (A)   No person licensed to sell alcoholic liquors under this chapter shall
permit his establishment to be open for business except during the following
periods of times:
      (1)   From 6:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following morning on Monday,
Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday;
      (2)   From 6:00 a.m. to 3:00 a.m. the following morning on Friday and
Saturday; and
      (3)   From 6:00 a.m. until 1:00 a.m. the following morning on Sunday.
   (B)   The only persons or individuals permitted to remain after closing
hours in an establishment which has been issued a Class “A” Retail Liquor
License, shall be the owner, bartender and janitor.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 665, passed 9-21-83; Am. Ord. 1516,
passed 9-4-13; Am. Ord. 1696, passed 12-19-18) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.45 EMPLOYMENT OF MINORS.
   No person, firm or corporation having a local license issued under this
chapter shall employ any minor to sell, draw, pour or mix any alcoholic liquor.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.46 GAMBLING DEVICES PROHIBITED.
   No gambling device of any kind shall be kept or used for the purpose of
gambling in any such establishment store or club, to barter, sell, exchange or
give away alcoholic liquors as defined herein except when operated in
compliance with the rules and requirements of the Video Gaming Act, ILCS Ch.
230, Act 40, §§ 1 et seq.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 1535, passed 3-5-14) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.47 CONDITIONS FOR OPERATING BEER GARDEN.
   No beer garden shall be permitted, maintained or operated except in
conformity with the following regulations:
   (A)   The beer garden area shall be particularly described and adjacent to,
and operated as part of, premises licensed to sell beer or alcoholic beverages
for consumption on the premises.
   (B)   Beer gardens shall be no greater in area than one and one-half the
other floor space of the licensed premises.
   (C)   Beer gardens shall be limited to one person for each ten square feet
and shall have separately posted the maximum capacity.
   (D)   At any part of the beer garden not blocked by a building, there shall
be maintained or constructed a hedge or fence not less that three feet high
surrounding the beer garden area. The fence shall contain the required fire
exit or exits. Each gate or exit shall be not less than three feet high, shall
swing to egress, shall be equipped with proper hardware, and shall swing free
and clear of public sidewalks. The beer garden fence shall comply with all city
ordinances regarding vision clearance and required distances from corners.
   (E)   All electrical wiring shall comply with the national, state and city
electrical codes.
   (F)   All combustible rubbish shall be stored in noncombustible covered
containers.
   (G)   The noise emanating from any beer garden shall not violate any
regulations of the Municipal Code or ordinances pertaining to noise.
   (H)   The licensee or his agent shall be responsible for preventing
violations of the section.
   (I)   No license shall be granted that violates any other provisions of the
liquor code including but not limited to location restrictions, days of
restricted sales, and other standards of operation.
(Am. Ord. 778, passed 7-1-92) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.48 CARRY LIQUOR FROM PREMISES OF A BEER GARDEN PROHIBITED.
   No person holding a Class “E” liquor license shall permit any patron to
carry liquor from the premises of the beer garden onto any street, roadway,
boulevard, avenue, parking lot or sidewalk in the city or onto any grounds
under the control of a public school district within the city.
(Am. Ord. 778, passed 7-1-92) Penalty, see §
112.99
§ 112.49 SIDEWALK CAFÉ SUPPLEMENTAL LIQUOR LICENSE.
   (A)   Application. The holder of a sidewalk café permit under
Ch. 122 that also holds a Class “A”, “B”, or “D” liquor license for the
building immediately adjacent to a permitted sidewalk café permit may make
application to the Liquor Control Commissioner to allow liquor to be served in
the permitted sidewalk café area. An application for a sidewalk café
supplemental liquor license shall be made similar to the application for a
Class “E” Beer Garden Supplemental License and must include proof of issuance
of a sidewalk café permit.
   (B)   Conditions for operation. The applicant for a sidewalk cade
supplemental liquor license shall comply with the following conditions for
operation:
      (1)   The sidewalk café area shall be particularly described and adjacent
to, and operated as part of, the premises licensed to sell beer or alcoholic
beverages for consumption on the premises.
      (2)   The serving of any liquor shall be limited to the consumption of
such while a customer is consuming food at the sidewalk café. No liquor shall
be served to a customer unless the customer is consuming food. No person shall
be allowed to consume liquor other than such purchased at the premises. No
customer shall be allowed to leave the sidewalk café area with liquor purchased
for consumption at the sidewalk café.
      (3)   No liquor shall be served in any glass container.
      (4)   The licensee shall be responsible for assuring compliance with the
above requirements, requirements for the application of a sidewalk café, and
general compliance by customers with this Code and criminal statutes.
      (5)   The sidewalk café supplemental liquor license shall automatically
terminate upon the termination of the required sidewalk café permit. A liquor
control hearing shall be conducted for all other violations.
   (C)   Applicant shall provide proof of liquor liability (dramshop) insurance
for the sidewalk café, in no less than statutory amounts and the insurance
shall name the city as an additional insured on a primary, non-contributory
basis.
   (D)   All licenses issued under this section shall run concurrently with the
applicant’s liquor license and shall require an annual fee of $25.
   (E)   A sidewalk café supplemental liquor license shall be for the exclusive
use of the licensed premises and cannot be assigned.
(Ord. 1482, passed 6-6-12; Am. Ord. 1490, passed 7-18-12)
§ 112.50 SHIPPING OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR.
   (A)   Shipping authorized. The holder of retailer's liquor licenses issued
by the city is authorized to perform shipping of alcoholic liquor from the
retailer to a consumer through one of the following methods:
      (1)   Delivery within licensed retailer's parking lot, including
curbside, for pickup by the consumer;
      (2)   Delivery by an owner, officer, director, shareholder, or employee
of the licensed retailer; or
      (3)   Delivery by a third-party contractor, independent contractor, or
agent with whom the licensed retailer has contracted to make deliveries of
alcoholic liquors.
   (B)   Delivery outside of parking lot or curbside. Any person delivering
alcoholic liquor outside of the parking lot or curbside for the holder of a
retailer's liquor license shall register their identity with the Marseilles
Police Department and agree to delivery terms including as follows:
      (1)   The delivery person shall be 21 years of age or older and within
the past year have completed a BASSET training program approved by the Illinois
Liquor Commission.
      (2)   The delivery shall be made within 12 hours from the time the
alcoholic liquor leaves the premises of the holder of a retailer's liquor
license any may be delivered only within hours authorized under §
112.44.
      (3)   No delivery may be made to person under 21 years of age and the
person accepting delivery shall sign a receipt for such on a receipt form
approved by the Marseilles Police Department.
      (4)   The holder of a retailer's liquor license shall hold liquor
delivery receipts for a period no less than 12 months and upon request shall
provide copies to the Marseilles Police Department.
(Ord. 1814, passed 1-19-21)
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
§ 112.60 COMPENSATION FOR MAYOR AS LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER.
   The annual compensation for the services of the Mayor as Local Liquor
Control Commissioner shall be $1,200 payable in equal monthly payments.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.61 CITY CLERK TO BE SECRETARY FOR COMMISSIONER.
   The City Clerk shall be the Secretary for the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner and assist in keeping the necessary records pertaining or
incidental thereto.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.62 APPOINTMENT OF ASSISTANT LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONERS.
   The Mayor shall appoint two Assistant Local Liquor Control Commissioners to
assist the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. The two Assistants shall be the
Commissioner of Finance and the Commissioner of Pubic Health and Safety, either
of whom shall exercise the duties of Local Liquor Control Commissioner in his
absence or at his direction. Each such Assistant shall be entitled to
reimbursement for all expenses incurred while exercising the duties of the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.63 EMERGENCY CLOSINGS; AUTHORITY OF MAYOR.
   In all cases where in the opinion of the Mayor, the public peace is likely
to be endangered by the keeping open of premises licensed hereunder, it shall
be lawful for the Mayor to issue his proclamation, under the seal of the city
commanding and enjoining all persons licensed by said city to sell any of said
liquors, and their servants and agents, to close their shops and places of
business for such time as the Mayor shall deem necessary; and neither to sell,
give away, or suffer to be drawn, any of said liquors in or about their
premises during the time mentioned in said proclamation.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82)
§ 112.64 APPEALS.
   All appeals from decisions of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner to
revoke or suspend any license issued by him, or the imposition of any fine
imposed by him, shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 7-9 of
the Illinois Control Act (ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 7-9). All such appeals shall
be limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings before the
Liquor Control Commissioner.
(Ord. 964, passed 4-7-99)
§ 112.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter for which
another penalty is not provided shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine
according to the Uniform Fine Schedule in §
10.99. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
   (B)   The penalty described in above division (A) shall not limit the
authority of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner to take action against a
responsible party under the Liquor Control Act of 1934, being ILCS Ch. 235, Act
5, to impose any penalty authorized under ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 7-5 or other
applicable section of said Act.
(Am. Ord. 633, passed 7-7-82; Am. Ord. 1326, passed 2-20-08 )

§ 113.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No circus, carnival, theater, concert, exhibition, show, entertainment or
amusement of any kind for the witnessing of which an admission fee is charged,
unless given under the auspices and for the benefit of an association or
society or church or charitable purpose, shall be given, exhibited, or
performed within the city without a license therefor.
('72 Code § 32.08(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99

subchapter the following fees:
Type of License Fees

SKATING RINKS
§ 113.15 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public skating rink in the city
without a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.09(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.16 QUALIFICATIONS AND INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT.
   No license shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral
character nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the
city by a person of good moral character. It shall be the duty of the Chief of
Police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each
applicant and report the results of such investigation to the City Clerk.
('72 Code, § 32.09(b))
§ 113.17 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual license fee for public skating rinks is $50 for each rink.
('72 Code, § 32.09(c))
§ 113.18 EXITS.
   It shall be unlawful to conduct a public skating rink in any hall or
building which is not equipped with sufficient and adequate exits and no hall
or building which is not provided with at least two exits of four feet or more
in width shall be used for such purpose.
('72 Code, § 32.09(d)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.19 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to indulge in or permit any improper conduct at
any public skating rink.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to permit music at any public skating rink after
11:00 p.m.
('72 Code, § 32.09(e)) Penalty, see §
10.99
BILLIARDS AND POOL TABLES
§ 113.30 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall keep any billiard or pool table to be used or placed upon by
others for hire or game in the city without a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.11(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.31 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license under this subchapter is $25 per year, for each table.
('72 Code, § 32.11(b))
§ 113.32 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   All billiard and pool rooms within this city shall close games at 11:00 p.m.
(12:00 p.m. Friday and Saturday only), and shall not be opened before 7:00 a.m
except that if the room is within a business licensed to sell alcoholic liquor,
the hours of operation shall correspond with the hours authorized to sell
alcoholic liquor.
(‘72 Code, § 32.11(c)) (Am. Ord. 605, passed 3-19-80; Am. Ord. 1536, passed 4-
2-14) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.33 USE BY MINORS.
   No keeper of any billiard or pool room where liquor is served or consumed on
the premises shall permit any person under the age of 18 years to play at any
game upon any table kept by him, nor shall he permit any such person to
frequent his place of business, or to loiter or remain therein unless such
person shall be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
('72 Code, § 32.11(c)) (Am. Ord. 605, passed 3-19-80) Penalty, see §
10.99
BOWLING ALLEYS
§ 113.45 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open to the public in
the city without a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.12(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.46 LICENSE FEE.
   No fee shall be required for such license.
(‘72 Code, § 32.12(b)) (Am. Ord. 1536, passed 4-2-14)
§ 113.47 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   No person operating or maintaining a bowling alley shall permit his
establishment to be open for business except during the following period of
time: from 6:00 a.m. of each day until 12:00 p.m., except on Saturday night
when the closing hour shall be 1:00 a.m., and except that if the alley is
within a business licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, the hours of operation
shall correspond with the hours authorized to sell alcoholic liquor.
(‘72 Code, § 32.12(c)) (Am. Ord. 1536, passed 4-2-14) Penalty, see §
10.99
TABLE GAMES
§ 113.60 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   OPERATOR. Any person who sets up for operation by another, or leases or
distributes for the purpose of operation by another, any table game for his own
use or profit, or owns any table game as herein defined, whether such setting
up for operation, leasing or distributing be for a fixed charge or rental or on
the basis of a division of the income derived from such table games, or
otherwise, or if an owner, whether or not he is entitled to full amount of
revenue derived therefrom.
   PROPRIETOR. Any person who is the distributee or lessee of any table game
placed in the establishment of such person in or at which such table game is
placed for use or play, or in the exhibition for the purpose of use or play,
such table game not being owned by such person.
   TABLE GAME. Any device, whether controlled by skill or chance, for the
operation of a game, pastime or contest by the manipulation of a marble,
sphere, or of objects or figures, or by controlling the movements of the same
or setting them in motion by mechanical means. The term TABLE GAME shall
include pinball machines.
('72 Code, § 32.13(a))
§ 113.61 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to conduct, own, operate, maintain or expose for public
use any table games or amusement device operated with a slug or coin for the
use of which a fee is charged, without a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.13(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.62 LICENSE FEES.
   No person shall engage in the business of an operator or proprietor as
hereinabove defined, without a license therefor. The license fee for each
proprietor and operator shall be $25 per year for each machine used or played,
or exhibited for use or play, payable May 1 of each year. For any license
issued on or after November 1 of any calendar year, the license fee shall be
one-half of the annual amount specified in this section, but there shall be no
further fractional division of license fees payable under this chapter.
('72 Code, § 32.13(b)) (Am. Ord. 605, passed 3-19-80)
§ 113.63 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; CONTENTS.
   (A)   Application for license hereunder shall be filed in writing with the
City Clerk and shall specify:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant and, if a firm, corporation,
partnership or association, the principal officers thereof and their addresses.
      (2)   Whether the applicant is a citizen of the United States.
      (3)   The place where the business of the applicant is to be carried on.
      (4)   The name of the manufacturer of the game and the type of game, the
number of games to be used in the city, and the serial or factory number of
each machine.
   (B)   The application shall be referred to the Council for investigation of
the character of the applicant, the premises in which it is proposed to carry
on the business of the applicant, and the type of game to be used. Such license
shall be non-assignable and non-transferable, and in the case of a proprietor
shall apply only to the premises for which such license is issued.
('72 Code, § 32.13(c))
§ 113.64 ISSUANCE AND DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   The City Clerk shall issue to each proprietor a license hereunder, listing
the number and type of machines for which the proprietor is licensed; such
license shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises for which it
is issued.
('72 Code, § 32.13(d)) (Am. Ord. 605, passed 3-19-80)
§ 113.65 USE BY MINORS.
   No proprietor of an establishment where liquor is to be served or consumed
on the premises shall permit any person under the age of 18 years to operate,
use or place such machine unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
('72 Code, § 32.13(e)) (Am. Ord. 605, passed 3-19-80) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.66 LOCATION OF MACHINES.
   All machines shall at all times be kept and placed in plain view of all
persons who may be in or frequent any place of business or other place where
such machines are kept or used.
('72 Code, § 32.13(f)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 113.67 USE FOR GAMBLING PROHIBITED.
   Nothing in this subchapter authorizes any table game to be used for gambling
purposes.
('72 Code, § 32.13(f))

AUCTIONEERS
§ 114.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No sale of personal property, except sales made under legal process, shall
be made within this city by auctioneer or any other person, unless he shall
first obtain a license from the City Clerk therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.01(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.02 BOND.
   Every person desiring to sell goods at auction within this city shall
execute a bond to the city in the penal sum of $100, conditioned for the
observance of all provisions of this code and other ordinances of the city
respecting auctions and auctioneers, which bond shall be filed with the
application of such person for license.
('72 Code, § 32.01(b))
§ 114.03 LICENSE FEE.
   (A)   There shall be charged for every license granted to any auctioneer
under the provisions of this subchapter:
      (1)   For one year, $50.
      (2)   For six months, $35.
      (3)   For three months, $20.
      (4)   For one day, $3.
   (B)   No license shall issue for any term except as above provided, except
that a license may be issued for any number of days upon the payment of the sum
of $3 for every day such license is desired.
('72 Code, § 32.01(c))
§ 114.04 DECEIVING BIDDERS.
   No person shall exhibit and offer for sale at auction any article and induce
its purchase by any bidder, and shall afterward substitute any other article
for the one so exhibited with the intent to deceive and defraud such bidder.
('72 Code, § 32.01(d)) Penalty, see §
10.99
JUNK DEALERS
§ 114.15 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall within this city keep any shop, store or other place, or
shall engage in the business of transient junk dealers, for the purchase, sale
or barter of junk, old metal and second-hand articles, without first having
obtained a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.02(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.16 GRANTING OF LICENSE; FEE.
   (A)   The Mayor and City Clerk are hereby authorized to grant a license
under this subchapter to any person of good moral character upon such applicant
paying the license fee therefor, and entering into a bond in the penal sum of
$100 to the city, conditioned that the applicant will observe all ordinances of
the city regulating such activity and will pay all fines and damages incurred
on account of his failure in that behalf.
   (B)   The license fee is $35 per year for a junk shop, and $5 per day for a
transient junk dealer with a vehicle only.
('72 Code, § 32.02(b))
§ 114.17 INSPECTIONS.
   Every junk shop within this city and all articles contained therein, may at
any time be examined by the Mayor, Chief of Police or any commissioner of the
city. No person shall interfere or attempt to interfere with any such
examination.
('72 Code, § 32.02(c))
§ 114.18 PURCHASE OF ARTICLES FROM MINORS.
   No junk dealer shall at any time purchase or receive any article or thing
from any minor without the consent in writing of the parent or guardian of such
minor child for the sale or disposition of such article or thing.
('72 Code, § 32.02(d)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.19 RECORDS TO BE KEPT.
   Every junk dealer shall keep a book in which shall be fairly written in the
English language in ink at the time of each purchase or receipt, an accurate
description of each article or thing purchased or received, the time of
purchasing or receipt of it, and the name, place of residence and occupation of
the seller. No entry made in such book shall be erased, obliterated or defaced.
Such book shall be open at all times to the inspection of the Mayor, Chief of
Police, or any member of the police force, or commissioner, or other person
authorized by them to inspect such book.
('72 Code, § 32.02(e))
§ 114.20 RESALE OF ARTICLES.
   No article purchased or received by any junk dealer shall be sold or
otherwise disposed of until at least one week from the date of its purchase or
receipt shall have elapsed.
('72 Code, § 32.02(f)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 114.21 STOLEN GOODS.
   Any junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles
or things which have been lost or stolen, or alleged to have been lost or
stolen, shall, upon demand to view and examine the same, produce such goods or
articles or things to the Chief of Police or any member of the police force.
('72 Code, § 32.02(g))

SCAVENGERS
§ 115.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger,
or the collection or disposal of animal, human or vegetable refuse, or offal,
without a license therefor. The fee for such license is $5 per year.
('72 Code, § 32.07(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 115.02 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Applications for such license shall be made to the City Clerk, and shall be
referred by him to the City Council. No such license shall be issued except on
order of the Council.
('72 Code, § 32.07(b))
§ 115.03 SPECIFICATIONS FOR VEHICLES.
   Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight, and
equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the
transportation of refuse.
('72 Code, § 32.07(c))
§ 115.04 DISPOSAL OR STORAGE OF REFUSE.
   It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in
any place within the city limits excepting with the permission of the City
Council.
('72 Code, § 32.07(d)) Penalty, see §
10.99
SHOOTING GALLERIES
§ 115.15 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall within the city keep any shooting gallery to be used by
others for hire or gain, without a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.10(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 115.16 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for such license is $24 per year or $1 per day.
('72 Code, § 32.10(b))
§ 115.17 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   All shooting galleries within the city shall remain closed on Sunday, and on
weekdays shall close at 10:00 p.m. and shall not be opened before 8:00 a.m.
('72 Code, § 32.10(c)) Penalty, see §
10.99
TRANSIENT PHOTOGRAPHERS
§ 115.30 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of resident,
transient or itinerant portrait or commercial photography, or in the enlarging,
copying, coloring or portrait finishing of photographs, or to solicit or offer
for sale any of such goods or services verbally, by telephone, by mail, or by
means of printed advertising in the city, without a license therefor.
('72 Code, § 32.04(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 115.31 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license under this subchapter is $25 per year or any fraction
thereof, and in addition a license fee of $5 per day or any fraction thereof
shall be paid by the licensee for each outside solicitor or salesperson,
including solicitors or salespersons so employed but operating from their own
temporary or permanent residences or telephones and whether paid on a salary or
commission basis, contracted with or employed by each person, for the purposes
of selling, distributing or securing orders for portrait or commercial
photographs, or for the enlarging, copying, coloring or portrait finishing
thereof, or for the selling or distribution of coupons or tokens, or other
printed or similar offers or advertising literature pledged or used in the sale
of portrait or commercial photographs or the enlarging, copying, coloring or
portrait finishing thereof.
('72 Code, § 32.04(b))
§ 115.32 BOND; AGENT FOR PURPOSE.
   (A)   Before the City Clerk shall issue any license under this subchapter,
the applicant shall execute an indemnity bond in the amount of $500 to the city
for the use and benefit of the patrons of said person who are residents of the
city. The bond shall have as surety either a regularly licensed corporate
surety company or a resident and real property owner of LaSalle County,
Illinois, who shall be worth at least the sum of $1,000 above his debts and
exemptions in property subject to execution and sale, and who shall make an
affidavit to that effect before signing as surety. In lieu of surety, $500 in
cash may be deposited with the Clerk, to be returned without interest by the
Clerk to the applicant within 30 days after the end of the license period or
any renewal period thereof.
   (B)   The applicant shall further appoint the Clerk as his process agent in
all matters connected with or arising out of the applicant's business. It shall
be the duty of the Clerk immediately to advise the applicant by registered
mail, addressed to the applicant at his place of business at the address
furnished in the indemnity bond, of the nature and pendency of any action
brought against the applicant wherein process is served on the Clerk.
('72 Code, § 32.04(c))

HAWKERS, PEDDLERS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND TRANSIENT VENDORS
§ 116.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, whether for himself or an agent for another, shall engage in the
pursuit or business of hawker, peddler, itinerant merchant or transient vendor
of merchandise without a license to do so.
('72 Code, § 32.03(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 116.02 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for such license shall state the name and residence of the
person desiring the license, the period of time for which it is desired and the
particular articles, things or merchandise to be sold, and whether it is
desired to pass from place to place in the city or locate at a fixed point or
place; and, if it is desired to locate at a fixed point or place, the location
shall be stated.
('72 Code, § 32.03(b))
§ 116.03 LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for a license under this subchapter is $30 for each month of
operation due at the time of application.
(‘72 Code, § 32.03(c)) (Ord. 909, passed 8-6-97; Am. Ord. 1511, passed 6-5-13)
§ 116.04 WHEN LICENSE NOT REQUIRED.
   No license shall be required from any civic, benevolent, charitable,
educational or not-for-profit organization or corporation.
('72 Code, § 32.03(d)) (Ord. 909, passed 8-6-97)
§ 116.05 SCOPE OF LICENSE.
   (A)   No person whether or not required to be licensed under the provisions
of this subchapter, shall occupy or use the public sidewalks, streets, alleys
or other public places while engaged in the pursuit or business of hawker,
peddler, itinerant merchant or transient vendor of merchandise; excepting,
however, unless authorized pursuant to the provisions of §
97.021(E).
   (B)   Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, no license shall
be issued to any person for a fixed point or location unless the applicant is
the owner or lessee of said location, and provides written evidence thereof
with the application for license.
   (C)   Transient vendors shall only be authorized to sell merchandise, food
or non-alcoholic beverages on a seasonal basis not to exceed six consecutive
months. Transient vendors shall not sell merchandise, food, or non-alcoholic
beverages out of a moving vehicle, but shall conduct business out of a
permanent or stationary structure.
(Am. Ord. 759, passed 6-5-91; Am. Ord. 909, passed 8-6-97; Am. Ord. 1511,
passed 6-5-13)
Cross-reference:
   Encroachments on streets; permit required, see §
97.021
§ 116.06 CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.
   No person, whether for himself or an agent for another, shall engage in the
pursuit of business of hawker, peddler, itinerant merchant or transient vendor
of merchandise without a current certificate of registration issued under the
Retailers Occupation Tax Act.
(Ord. 909, passed 8-6-97) Penalty, see §
10.99
SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
§ 116.15 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon any private residence,
apartment or premises in the city for the purpose of soliciting from the
occupants thereof, or to canvass for orders for goods, wares, merchandise or
services of any character or description, or for the purpose of offering to
give or to furnish or giving or furnishing any goods, wares, merchandise or
services to any such occupants to induce or invite such orders, without having
first received from the Chief of Police a solicitor's permit to do so.
('72 Code, § 32.05(a)) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 116.16 APPLICATION; CONTENTS.
   (A)   Any person desiring to secure such a solicitor's permit shall apply
therefor in writing over his signature to the Chief of Police on forms provided
by the city. Such application shall state:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;
      (2)   The name and address of the person by whom employed;
      (3)   The length of service of such applicant with such employer;
      (4)   The place of residence and nature of employment of the occupant
during the last preceding year;
      (5)   The nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or service
to be offered by the applicant;
      (6)   The personal description and complete identification of the
applicant.
   (B)   Such application shall be accompanied by such credentials and other
evidence of the good moral character and identity of the applicant, as may be
reasonably required by the Chief of Police.
('72 Code, § 32.05(b))
§ 116.17 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; DURATION.
   If the Chief of Police shall determine after reasonable investigation that
the applicant is of good moral character and proposes to engage in a lawful and
legitimate commercial or professional enterprise, he shall then issue the
permit applied for, which permit shall expire on December 31 of the year
issued.
('72 Code, § 32.05(c))
§ 116.18 REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   Any such permit may be revoked by the Chief of Police for violations by the
holder thereof of this code or any other ordinances of the city or of any state
or federal law, or whenever the holder of such permit shall cease to possess
the character and qualifications required by this subchapter for the issuance
of such permit.
('72 Code, § 32.05(d))
§ 116.19 TIME LIMIT ON SOLICITING AND CANVASSING.
   It is unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person whether
registered under this subchapter or not, to go upon any premises for the
purpose of engaging in soliciting or canvassing prior to 8:30 a.m. or after 5:
30 p.m.
('72 Code, § 32.05(e)) (Am. Ord. 568, passed 4-3-78) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 116.20 SOLICITOR AND CANVASSER PERMIT FEE.
   The fee for a solicitor or canvasser permit under this subchapter is $30 for
each month of operation.
(Ord. 1511, passed 6-5-13)
CHAPTER 117: TAXICABS
Section
   
117.01   Definition
